segments.en: 7. A Question About the Dimension of Nothingness
“They speak of this thing called the ‘dimension of nothingness’.
What is the dimension of nothingness?

segments.pli: ‘idha bhikkhu sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma natthi kiñcīti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
segments.en: ‘It’s when a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that “there is nothing at all”, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness.
This is called the dimension of nothingness.’

segments.pli: So khvāhaṃ, āvuso, sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma natthi kiñcīti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
segments.en: And so … I was entering and remaining in the dimension of nothingness.

segments.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, āvuso, iminā vihārena viharato viññāṇañcāyatanasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti.
segments.en: While I was in that meditation, perceptions and attentions accompanied by the dimension of infinite consciousness beset me.

segments.pli: Atha kho maṃ, āvuso, bhagavā iddhiyā upasaṅkamitvā etadavoca:
segments.en: Then the Buddha came up to me with his psychic power and said,

segments.pli: Mā, brāhmaṇa, ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ pamādo, ākiñcaññāyatane cittaṃ saṇṭhapehi, ākiñcaññāyatane cittaṃ ekodiṃ karohi, ākiñcaññāyatane cittaṃ samādahā’ti.
segments.en: Don’t neglect the dimension of nothingness, brahmin! Settle your mind in the dimension of nothingness; unify your mind and immerse it in the dimension of nothingness.’

segments.pli: So khvāhaṃ, āvuso, aparena samayena sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma natthi kiñcīti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja vihāsiṃ.
segments.en: And so, after some time … I entered and remained in the dimension of nothingness.

segments.pli: Yañhi taṃ, āvuso, sammā vadamāno vadeyya … pe … mahābhiññataṃ patto”ti.
segments.en: So if anyone should be rightly called a disciple who attained to great direct knowledge with help from the Teacher, it’s me.”

suttaplex.blurb: Moggallāna speaks to the mendicants of a time when his practice of the dimension of nothingness was faltering. He expresses his gratitude for the Buddha, who urged him to stabilize that attainment.
